boardgame.name: 1944: Carrera hacia el Rin
1944: Carrera hacia el Rin
1944: Race to the Rhine
1944: Wyścig do Renu
boardgame.description:
Not enough gas, not enough ammo or not enough time. Not enough to cross the Rhine before the enemy closes all the gaps. You need to form the bridgehead before others do. That’s the only way to Victory and your personal glory.

1944 Race to the Rhine is a new game experience. You can’t win this game without proper planning. Your tanks need gas to move and ammo to fight. But don’t forget to feed your GIs. So what would be your transport priority?

Will you follow General Patton’s strategy to discard ammo in order to bring additional fuel barrels along to move boldly forward? Would you risk your prestige and gamble on Market-Garden as Field Marshal Montgomery did? Would you cross the Rhine more quickly than General Bradley did, with the help of your hard work and a little luck?

“In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispensable” (General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe).

So, how are you planning your Victory?

Grim World is a dark fantasy supplement for the Dungeon World and Fate Core systems


7+ Dungeon World class playbooks

boardgame.name: MovieMashups
boardgame.description:
A team game, where each team tries to determine the mashed up movie title.
Scoring is one point for each title guessed, and a bonus point for both titles. If there are points left over after the 1 minute round, the other team gets a chance to steal the remaining points. Whomever gets the most points gets the card. At the end of the game, you take the cards and try to make combos (most movies starring same actor, most in the same series, most in same genre).

As it's a team game, you will see one person knowing a title, announcing it, then the other team members using that title to guess the rest of the movies. Also, sometimes a player knows the movie but cannot remember its title, so will describe the movie to their teammates. Those are fun moments for me to see.

You will see an opponent anxiously watching the clock for opportunity to steal.

The numbers at the bottom of the card are used to create themed decks. This lets you use a sub-set of the cards you own to come up with a themed game.

boardgame.name: WWII: The Card Game
boardgame.description:
September 1, 1939 – For the second time in the 20th century, the world is at war. With the invasion of Poland by Germany, Europe plunges into war a mere 20 years after the end of The Great War, now to be known as World War I. Just over two years later, in December of 1941, the other half of the globe joins the war as Japan declares war on the United States and the British Commonwealth and tears through Western Pacific territories with astonishing ease. Will you save the free world as the Allies, or conquer it as the Axis?

WWII: The Card Game is a 2 player card game that pits the Axis against the Allied Powers in the Second World War. WWII: The Card Game is a constructed deck game in which both players construct their own deck before the game begins and then use their deck to wage war on their opponent. During the game, players build their resources and deploy military units to take control of locations by defeating their opponent’s units in battle. By winning battles and controlling key strategic locations around the world, players cause their opponent to lose cards from their deck. The first player to empty their opponent’s deck is the winner!

Bride of Pin•Bot was released in 1991 by Williams and is the second in the Pin•Bot trilogy of tables. On this table, the goal is to transform Pin•Bot's bride, giving her speech, sight and eventually a transformation into human form. The table also has a Billion Point shot - the largest scoring feature in pinball history.

User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Cirqus Voltaire was released in 1997 by Bally. Funhouse was released in 1990 by Williams. A talking head called Rudy is the star of this table. He speaks to the player and follows the ball with his eyes. The main goal of this table is to hit targets that advance the clock to midnight, which sends Rudy to sleep. Sending the ball into his mouth as he snores starts a multiball mode which offers the chance to score big points!

boardgame.name: Table Pack 3: Monster Bash and Gorgar
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Monster Bash was released in 1998 by Williams and features six iconic Universal Studios monsters playing in a rock band! The goals of the table involve waking the monsters and supplying them with their instruments. The table featured a 'phantom flip' feature where the table would play shots without the user touching the flippers!

Gorgar was released in 1979 by Williams, and was the first talking pinball machine, with a vocabulary of seven words which are linked into short phrases such as "Gorgar hurt" or "Me got you!". The table features a battle between the player and a demon creature, the titular Gorgar. There is no music, instead the soundtrack is a heartbeat, which grows faster and faster as Gorgar grows closer to defeat.

boardgame.name: Circus Divas
boardgame.description:
In Circus Divas, a two-player dice-buying game, you play the owner of a Depression-era circus going from town to town parting fools and their money. But in order to do that, you need to hire some help and, ultimately, earn more than the rival circus that keeps hitting the same towns you do and draining your profits.

Each player can hire performers for his or her circus from a common pool. Those performers each allow the player to roll one additional die for profit, from the lowly d4 to the mighty - but unpredictable - d20. But these performers can prove to be real divas. When a performer rolls a 1, he or she throws a diva's tantrum and has to be consoled - or he or she will quit. And if you're consoling one diva, you can't console another if they should have a tantrum, so choose carefully.

The first player to reach $100 in savings wins. Play time takes about 15 minutes and requires at least one d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20 to play. Counters for money are also helpful, but pencil and paper could work just fine. Enjoy it, and please let me know what you think!

boardgame.description:
Ascend: Hand of Kul (formerly Ascend: New Gods) is a 2013 free-to-play game for the Xbox 360 and Microsoft Windows. It was unveiled at the Electronic Entertainment Expo 2012 during Microsoft's press conference. It is currently available in the Xbox Live Arcade.

The game features parallel multiplayer, wherein the player goes about his or her own single-player adventure, but can see other players going about their single-player adventures at the same time. The player cannot work together as in traditional co-op modes, but can purchase and send "blessings" and "curses" to one another.

Source: Wikipedia, "Ascend: Hand of Kul", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Age of Soccer
boardgame.description:
The "beautiful game" meets ancient mythology in the tactical board-based card game Age of Soccer as victory depends on getting the right balance between your player and action cards as well as a healthy dose of good fortune from the ancient deities. Will the deities reward their favorite players with divine powers? Or will they favor your opponents? Only time and skill will tell.

Age of Soccer is a card and hand management style game. Players are tasked with building their team's strength by recruiting new player cards in addition to adding powerful action cards to help influence a match and defeat opponents.

At the beginning of your turn, you must choose between strengthening your squad with new player cards or strengthening your hand with new action cards. Players use special training cards to help train their team or cause trouble for their opponents. Then players battle opposing teams using special match cards, trying to defeat them and gain a vital trophy.

Once a player has defeated all other teams in the game, he is crowned the champion of Age of Soccer.

boardgame.name: The Contested Isle: The Hibernian Tribunal
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

The magi of Hibernia respect the land and its supernatural inhabitants, granting much of the Tribunal's area to hedge traditions and allowing supernatural creatures a vote at Tribunal. Now, magi from elsewhere in the Order have come to "reform" the Peripheral Code, laying siege to and taking one of the Irish covenants. If the native magi could stop fighting each other, they would resist. As English lords push further into the island, and the Church struggles with attempts to make it fit continental ideals, the Order of Hermes faces its own conflict. The traces of past conflicts are everywhere: the faerie Tuatha De Danaan, the magic Fir Bolg and Formorach, and saints as prone to curse as bless. Demons, however, are nowhere to be seen, as constant fighting convulses the Emerald Isle. It is, as ever in Ireland, a time for heroes.

boardgame.name: Draw Blood
boardgame.description:
Draw Blood is a rummy-style card game for 2-3 players, with a deck that consists of 54 cards: three types of monsters (Vampires, Werewolves and Water Monsters), three "Kill" cards (for killing your opponent's Monsters), and 36 numbered blood cards.

Like most rummy games, the object of Draw Blood is to be the first player to get rid of all the cards in your hand. To do this, players can lay down melds of sets and runs; unlike other rummy games, however, you can't just lay down melds whenever you want. You must play a monster card first. Knowing when to play monsters is a key strategy, but you also have to figure out when to kill your opponent's monsters to prevent them from laying down their own melds.

The numbered blood cards come in two colors: odd numbers are black and have a skull in the right corner, while even numbers are red and have a heart in the right corner. You can kill your opponent's monsters with a Kill card or a three-of-a-kind of skulls. With a three-of-a-kind of hearts, you can bring one of your monsters back to life. Blood cards can also be played as melds for points, and deciding whether to play for points or to kill your opponents becomes a key strategy in the game.

The first player to play out his cards ends the hand, then everyone tallies his score. Whoever first reaches a preset point total wins!

boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

It's tough surviving in the big city when you've run out of money and can't find a job you really want to do (it's not much fun cleaning out stables) so when an admittedly strange person comes up to you offering the chance to earn serious coin who would turn it down? Especially when the job calls for a hero and you're sure you fit the bill.

Breaking into the Khaboom City Dungeons might be possible, especially with the funky key you've been provided with, even if it does mean a trip through the sewer system, but can you be sure that if you do go in you'll ever get out?

And what about the prisoner you're supposed to release? Just who or what do they keep on the maximum security level? Good luck - you'll probably need it!

Hope that's enough to set the scene (or bait the trap!).

Three hundred years before the Common Era, the shores of the Mediterranean Sea are inhabited by dozens of peoples, but only one of these nations is destined to found a great civilization that will spread from Egypt to Britannia. Take up the reigns of rule in your hands and prove that you are the only one worthy to unite half the world under your banner!

In Founders of the Empire, each player expands his own domain using four types of square tiles:


Green tiles represent natural landscapes: forests, cliffs, lakes, etc. They can be added to the players' domains freely. These tiles provide basic resources: wood, stone, plants and water.
Blue tiles are village buildings that require specific natural resources. For instance, the mine (which provides gold) should be placed next to stone and water sources.
Purple tiles represent city structures: marketplaces, inns, workshops and army camps. They also should be placed next to other tiles that give certain resources. In addition to providing corresponding resources, city tiles give their owners action tokens that can be used at any point of the game.
Red tiles are temples and altars that give players victory points. They are of different values (from 1 to 3 points) and require different combination of resources.


A player's turn consists of three phases. First, the player must add a new tile from the stack to the common market. Then, he has the option of playing one of his tokens; these tokens are able to buy opponents' resources, pillage enemy tiles, transfer resources between tiles, and convert resources to victory points. Finally, the player must add a tile from the market to his domain. The game ends after all red tiles are added to the players' domains. Each player calculates victory points from his temples and tokens, and the player with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Yōkaï no Mori
boardgame.description:
Yōkaï no Mori contains two simpler versions of Shogi to introduce the game to new players and youngsters.

In the classic version, each player has only four pieces – kodama, tanuki, kitsune, and koropokkuru – and they're trying to either catch the opponent's koropokkuru or move their own koropokkuru to the opposite side of the game board. The board is just 3×4 squares, so the game is rather short. As for how to play:


The tanuki moves one space orthogonally.
The kitsune moves one space diagonally.
The kodama is directly analogous to the pawn/soldier of Shōgi and can be promoted to a kodama samurai, equivalent to the gold general in Shogi (moving one space orthogonally or one space diagonally forward).
The koropokkuru is analogous to a king in Chess, except that he can win through promotion as long as it doesn't leave him in check.
Even on this 3×4 board, you are still able to drop in pieces that you captured from your opponent!
Unlike in Shōgi, you can drop a kodama for mate or have two kodama in a column.


The expert version has a larger 5×6 game board with each player having eight pieces (3 kodama, 2 oni, 2 kirin and 1 koropokkuru).


The kirin moves equivalent to the gold general in Shogi.
The oni moves equivalent to the silver general in Shogi (moving one space diagonally or one space straight forward) and can be promoted to a super oni, equivalent to the gold general in Shogi.


The game also adds more rules from the full Shōgi game, in particular:


You win only by capturing your opponent's koropokkuru, not by reaching the opposite side of the game board.
You can't have two of your own kodama in the same column/file.
You can't drop a kodama for mate.


The Japan Shogi Association created the rules for this game in order for players to learn important concepts in Shōgi, such as how to handle the generals effectively, why pawn promotion is so important, and how to mate the opponent's king with successive piece drops.

boardgame.name: Praedor (1st edition)
boardgame.description:
user summary:
Praedor RPG is one of the most sold finnish RPGs ever, this first edition had two print runs before the revision and 1.1 edition.

Translated from back of the book:
It is unknown whether Jaconia belongs to past or future. In some eternal universe it just is. Jaconia is a big round piece of free land in the middle of a long dead, dark civilization's ruins. Jaconia is surrounded by Borvaria, kingdom of death, miljons of square kilometers of ancient ruined city. Nobody knows what lies behind Borvaria, some religions say there is nothing at all. Borvaria is dead land. Eternal dark force and nameless creatures make it a dark hell. Praedors are adventurers who earn their living by robbing and pillaging the ruins of Borvaria and Warth.

'Praedor is a fantasy roleplaying game based on the world of Petri Hiltunens graphic novels with the same name. It tells about Jaconia, fragment of a world, left in the middle of the ruins of a super-culture, devastated by an ancient curse. It tells about praedors, talented and courageous adventurers, who make trips to the ruins of Borvaria in hope of treasures. They are the heroes and villains of legends, envied and hated upstarts. Among them, high and low are equal, because monsters and demons don't care about family trees.

Jaconia is also a lot more, nothing prevents you from playing crooked nobles, acid-burned alchemists, thiefs of big cities, clergy men, cultists et cetera. Almost 100 pages of World book is a great source for anyone interested in Jaconia. The whole book is awesomely illustrated by Petri Hiltunen himself and includes 15 comic pages describing different parts of Jaconia.

Game rules and text parts are made by Ville Vuorela, who's earlier creations are Miekkamies, Taiga and Mobsters and many projects using RPGs in higher education. Rules are easy to learn, but very detailed if needed. Values are easy to change to be compatible with other RPG systems or to take in use in another environment or game world.

boardgame.name: Pandemic
Pandemic: The Board Game
boardgame.description:
As skilled members of a disease-fighting team, you must keep four deadly diseases at bay while discovering their cures. Travel the world, treat infections, and find cures.
You must work as a team to succeed. The clock is ticking as outbreaks and epidemics fuel the spreading plagues. Can you find all four cures in time? The fate of humanity is in your hands!

Pandemic: The Board Game is a family-friendly cooperative game. Pandemic: The Board Game puts you in an apocalyptic situation where you must work as a team to save the world.

In Pandemic: The Board Game each player has a unique role with different abilities. On a turn, players will have four actions in order to cure diseases and save the world. They can remove disease cubes from the board; fly to a city in need; trade cards with fellow players; and much more.

At the end of every player’s turn, new cities are infected with disease cubes and Epidemics may arise. You must fight to prevent the outbreaks before they spin out of control.

While there are many ways to lose, there is only one way to win: cure all four diseases before you run out of time!

A hilarious, fast-paced card game reinforcing double digit addition skills.

Slide the stolen pile to your side of the table. Piles can be stolen over and over again. A Thief card can steal a money pile. A Jail card can steal a pile with a Thief card. The player with the most money when the cards run out wins.

boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

In den dunklen Straßenschluchten der Megaplexe lockt das Geschäft. Wo sich versteckte Unterschlupfe finden und Schieber illegale Aufträge für ihre Konzerne vermitteln, sind Shadowrunner zuhause. Von hier aus starten sie ihre geheimen Operationen und erleben Abenteuer in der Sechsten Welt.

Schattenstädte ist ein Hintergrundband für Shadowrun 4, in dem ein paar der wichtigsten Megaplexe beschrieben werden: Seattle, Hamburg, Hongkong und - neu in dieser Auflage - Marseille. Sie alle eignen sich durch ihr einzigartiges Flair besonders gut als Hintergrund für eine klassische Shadowrun-Kampagne. Dieses Buch gibt umfassenden Überblick über verschiedene Stadtteile, interessante Orte und die Machtkämpfe, die zwischen Politik, Konzernen, Syndikaten und Straßengangs toben. Zudem sind Kurzdossiers zu Kapstadt, Caracas und Istanbul enthalten, sowie zahlreiche Abenteuerideen und Tipps, mit deren Hilfe man beliebige andere Städte als Schattenstädte verwenden kann.

Diese neue Auflage von Schattenstädte ist für die beschriebenen Megaplexe aktualisiert bis zum Jahr 2072



Translation courtesy of Google:In the dark canyons of the megaplexes, the business attracts. Where to find hidden hideouts and fixers slide illegal orders for their corporations, Shadowrunners are at home. From here, they start their secret operations and experience adventures in the Sixth World.

Schattenstädte is a background sourcebook for Shadowrun 4, in which a few of the main megaplexes are described: Seattle, Hamburg, Hong Kong, and - new to this edition - Marseille. They all are with their unique flair particularly good as a background for a classic Shadowrun campaign. This book provides an comprehensive overview of various parts of the city, places of interest and power struggles raging between politicians, corporations , syndicates and gangs. In addition, short chapters on Cape Town, Caracas and Istanbul are included, as well as numerous adventure ideas and tips that will help you use any other cities as shadow cities.

This new edition of Schattenstädte updates information on the described cities to the year 2072



user description

Schattenstädte is the translation of Runner Havens with an added chapter on Hamburg in the shadows. The revised 2010 release by Pegasus also includes a translation of the chapter on marseilles from Capitales des ombres by French publisher BBE.



edition overview

Runner Havens was released in three different versions in Europe. All three add different city chapters to the ones on Seattle and Hong Kong included in the original:
Runner Havens (2006, fanpro US, 144 pages) - Main cities: Seattle, Hong Kong
Schattenstädte (2006, German translation by fanpro, 192 pages) - Main cities: Seattle, Hong Kong, Hamburg
Schattenstädte (Revised) (2010, German translation by Pegasus, 223 pages) - Main cities: Seattle, Hong Kong, Hamburg, Marseille
Capitales des ombres (2008, French translation by BBE) - Main cities: Seattle, Hong Kong, Marseille

boardgame.name: Turbo Rally Card Racing
boardgame.description:
Using your own 1:64 scale diecast cars, race opponents along rally themed card tracks that you create. The cards are expandable so you can challenge unlimited players and build courses as simple or as big as you can imagine.

On your turn, flip one track card over, and follow the signs as you race through jumps and obstacles toward the finish line. The first player to reach the winner's circle wins one of five trophies. Trophy winners earn performance upgrades like run-flat tires, off-road tires, turbo and driver agility cards that give boosts for one race.

RPM (Radical Performance Maneuvers) draw cards give players opportunities to boost ahead, burst through obstacles or sabotage opponents. Each player start with three RPM cards that can be played on theirs or an opponent's turn. Players earn more cards by landing on designated RPM track spaces. Multiple card combinations can be played to enhance effects or counter one another. RPMs last for one turn and include NOS, off-road tires, run-flat tires, green lights, tire spikes and sideswipes.

The player with the most trophies after five races is the tournament champion!

boardgame.name: Nubia
boardgame.description:
A board game that uses components of a checkers set. 22 pieces, 11 per player, and an 8x8 board. Layout: two diagonally opposite corners are labeled "Camps;" a player's counters are arranged in a diagonal pattern guarding his or her camp. (Please note: opening set-up of pieces has been revised.)

Movement: pieces move as a rook in chess. If a piece is making a non-capturing move, it can only move forward, toward the enemy Camp.

Capturing: this is done by moving away from an adjacent enemy counter. So, if at the start of your turn, an enemy piece is next to one of yours, you move away from it in a straight line to capture it.

Winning: the person who gets a counter onto the enemy's Camp wins.

boardgame.name: Ideas al Minuto
boardgame.description:
The object of Ideas al Minuto is to say as many ideas as possible in one minute.

In teams of 2-5, players receive challenges based on the cards that they draw. Within one minute, each team gives as many answers as possible on the same challenge, with the conditions changing each time thanks to drawn cards showing animals, characters, places and things. The first team, for example, might tell a story of a teacher who starts on an island and ends in a circus, while the next tells the story of a baker who begins in a hospital and ends in a submarine.

Each challenge card has a difficulty of 1-5, and team's score points based on this difficulty level. The team with most points at the end of the game wins.

boardgame.name: Templar Queenie 1: The Messages & The Coins
boardgame.description:
Templar Queenie 1: The Messages & The Coins, a mini-expansion for Templar: The Secret Treasures, consists of two modules that can be used individually, together, or in combination with any other modules for the game.


The Messages: Shuffle the seven message tiles with the harbor tiles at the start of the game. Whenever at least one message tile is revealed when adding tiles to the harbor, each player can either score 2 VP or return a played character card to hand.



The Coins: If no coins are on the board when someone plays "The Bells" card, place one coin in each room. When a player ends his movement in a room with a coin, he collects that coin. Players score 1-12 VP at the end of the game depending on how many coins they have relative to other players.

boardgame.name: Templar Queenie 2: The Secret Letters, The Tapestries & The Lamps
boardgame.description:
Templar Queenie 2: The Secret Letters, The Tapestries & The Lamps, a mini-expansion for Templar: The Secret Treasures, consists of three modules that can be used individually, together, or in combination with any other modules for the game.


The Secret Letters: Each player has one secret letter tile that he can discard to replay a (valid) character that's already in his discard stack. If unused, the secret letter tile is worth 3 VP at game's end.



The Tapestries: Each player has one tapestry tile that he can place in a room. When Remigius awards points in a room, anyone with a tapestry in the room scores twice as many points as normal, then all tapestries in the room are discarded. If unused, the tapestry tile is worth 3 VP at game's end.



The Lamps: Each player has one lamp tile that he can place in a room. When Remigius or Severus ends movement in a room with a lamp, the lamp's owner scores 2 VP, then reclaims his lamp, which can be placed again on a future turn.

boardgame.name: Templar Queenie 3: The Catacombs
boardgame.description:
Templar Queenie 3: The Catacombs, a mini-expansion for Templar: The Secret Treasures, consists of one module that can be used individually or in combination with any other modules for the game.


The Catacombs: This new room is placed adjacent to the game board. Players can pick up scrolls in the harbor, then deliver them to the catacombs to score 4 VP. In the advanced version of this module, a player must deliver one of signet rings in addition to the scroll; in addition to the 4 VP, he scores a bonus based upon how many of his rings are orthogonally adjacent to the ring just placed.

Templar Queenie 4: The Keys, a mini-expansion for Templar: The Secret Treasures, consists of one module that can be used individually or in combination with any other modules for the game.


The Keys: Each player has a key tile, and as long as he holds the tile, he gains 2 VP (instead of 1) when playing Porticus. He can discard the key tile to move his character, Remigius or Severus through a locked door. If he holds the key at game's end, it's worth 3 VP.

boardgame.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Villain Oversized Cards
boardgame.description:
The first draft of Sentinels of the Multiverse included oversized villain cards that had the art for that villain and all of that character's game text on one big card. These 4" by 6" cards represent the villains from the core game, expansions, mini-expansions, and promos.

The First Edition (2012) contains all villains from before Shattered Timelines, the Shattered Timelines Update Pack contains the villains released in the Shattered Timelines expansion and reprints of some misprinted cards from the First Edition, and Shattered Timelines Current Total Pack contains all villains to date with the reprints instead of the misprints.

In 2015, Sentinels of the Multiverse: Oversized Villain Cards was released with new cards not seen before.

boardgame.name: Shadowrun Einsteigerregeln v1
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Twenty-one pages of basic rules for Shadowrun released by Pegasus Spiele. This product has the same purpose as Catalyst's Shadowrun Quick-Start Rules, but was apparently developed independently by Pegasus for the German-language market. Similar in scope and design to Pegasus's offering Cthulhu für Einsteiger for Call of Cthulhu.

Later versions include the introductory scenario "freier Markt".

boardgame.name: Food Fight 4.0
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb

Die Schlacht ums Essen beginnt JETZT!

Wenn der Hunger kommt, gibt es nur einen Ort (besonders dann, wenn in ca. einer Stunde die Sonne aufgeht), wo man so etwas zu Mampfen bekommt. Ein Ort, den jeder hasst und liebt: Stuffer Shack.
Jepp, der gute alte Stuffer Shack, wo ein Geruch zu finden ist, den man nicht einordnen kann (und wohl auch nicht will) und wo sich Zeug zum Magenverderben im Wert von Tausenden Nuyen befindet. Und als wäre das nicht schon genug, ist der Laden auch noch 24 Stunden am Tag, 7 Tage die Woche, 365 Tage im Jahr geöffnet.

Food Fight 4.0 ist ideal, wenn Sie nur mal kurz in das Kampfsystem von Shadowrun 4 schnuppern möchte, die Gruppe wenig Zeit hat oder die Spieler nach dem Run im Einsteigerregelwerk noch ein wenig Auslauf brauchen. Es ist eine einfache und schmutzige Schlägerei mit nur sehr wenig Handlung, speziell dazu gestaltet, um dem Spielleiter und den Spielern ein Gefühl dafür zu vermitteln, wie die Regeln von Shadowrun funktionieren. Kümmern Sie sich zu diesem Zeitpunkt noch nicht zu sehr ums Rollenspiel, sondern konzentrieren Sie sich nur aufs Würfeln und haben einfach Spaß daran.


Translation courtesy of Google:

The battle for food begins NOW!

If you get hungry, there's only one place (especially if in about one hour, the sun comes up) where you get something to munch. A place that everyone hates and loves: Stuffer Shack.
Yep, the good old Stuffer Shack, where smells are to find that one can not classify (and probably doesn't want to), and where there's stuff to ruin your stomach worth thousands of Nuyen. And as if not enough, the store is also open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year.

Food Fight 4.0 is ideal if you just want to briefly sniff the combat system of Shadowrun 4, the group has little time or the players need a little run after the run in the introductory rules. It is a simple and dirty brawl with very little plot, specifically designed to to give the game master and the players a feel for how the rules of Shadowrun work. Do not even bother this time around too much with role-playing, but concentrate only onto the dice and just have fun with it.



User description

Originally part of Shadowrun Quick-Start Rules, German publisher Pegasus released the legendary Food Fight as a free pdf.

boardgame.name: Geben und Nehmen
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb

Weihnachten 2070 steht vor der Tür und nicht zum ersten Mal fragt ihr euch, ob die ganze Stadt verrückt geworden ist. Die große Werbeoffensive von DeMeKo hat bereits vor Wochen jedes vernünftige Maß weit hinter sich gelassen und gleicht immer mehr einem wahnsinnigen Gehirnwäschefeldzug. Kitschige Werbejingles donnern an jeder Straßenecke aus den Lautsprechern, unterbrochen nur vom ständigen Ho-Ho-Ho der Weihnachtsmänner. Armeen von Werbe-AROs bombardieren die Horden der Einkaufswütigen mit Schnäppchenangeboten und treiben sie wie hirntote Zombies durch die überfüllten Straßen und Kanäle zu den Konsumtempeln.

Aber Rettung naht: Heiligabend steht kurz bevor. Nur noch wenige Tage, dann werdet ihr friedvolle sechs Monate ohne Weihnachtswerbung durchleben können. Bis der ganze Wahnsinn wieder von vorne beginnt...



Translation courtesy of Google:Christmas 2070 is coming, and not for the first time, you wonder if the whole town has gone mad. The great advertising campaign of DeMeKo has left any reasonable measure far behind weeks ago and increasingly resembles an insane brainwashing campaign. Kitschy commercial jingles thunder on every street corner from the speakers, interrupted only by the constant Ho-Ho-Ho of Santa Claus. Armies of advertising AROs bomb shopping victims with hordes of bargain offers and drive them like brain-dead zombies through the crowded streets and canals to the shopping malls.

But salvation is near: Christmas Eve is imminent. Only a few days, then you will have peaceful six months to live through without Christmas advertising. Until all the madness starts all over again ...



User description

Winning entry of Pegasus' 2009 adventure competition for Shadowrun. Subsequently released as a free pdf.

boardgame.name: Treants
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This particular installment of Exotic Encounters focuses on the iconic treant. These paragons of nature may be fairly obvious homages to The Lord of the Rings’s ents, but that doesn’t make them any less of a staple of fantasy media, and tree-beings of all sorts are a fun and resonant part of fantasy. The first treant in this book, the jungle treant (CR 10), is more than just an ill-mannered treant from a more tropical clime: its long vines animate and lash out to trip or entangle foes, and its body serves as a host to several swarms of angry wasps. Even more terrifying, however, is the bonfire treant (CR 14), an evil, twisted treant that burns with a constant and hellish supernatural fire. Everything this creature touches bursts into flames, and such flames are all but impossible to extinguish as long as the creature still lives. The last treant in the book is the old growth treant (CR 16), a massive, towering treant from ancient times that can release a hail of deadly pine needles, and which daring adventurers can climb upon in order to better fight it.

boardgame.name: Dungeon of Deadliest Evil
boardgame.description:
The mad sorcerer Grislyk has stolen the Book of Lore from the elves and hidden it in his dungeon lair. As the elven warrior maiden Kora, you must brave three increasingly dangerous levels to recover the Book, destroy Grislyk’s magical Black Crucible, and slay the wizard himself. Magical artifacts will help you evade Grislyk’s traps and slay his army of goblins and skeletons, but you will also need your wits and a bit of luck, for knowing when to search, when to fight, and when to run is the only way to survive the DUNGEON OF DEADLIEST EVIL.

Dungeon of Deadliest Evil is a solitaire adventure game that takes all the essential elements of a classic dungeon crawl, like slaying monsters, finding powerful artifacts, and exploring a multi-level dungeon, and packs them into an easy-to-learn game that sets up and plays in 20 minutes.

Gameplay is based on a simple dice allocation mechanic. You have three abilities, Speed, Combat, and Defense, and at the start of each turn you must assign one of three dice (a d4, a d6, and a d8) to each of them. While the game involves a good deal of luck and dice-rolling, judicious dice allocation is the key to success. Victory is achieved by destroying the Black Crucible, retrieving the Book of Lore, slaying the evil wizard Grislyk, and finally leaving the dungeon alive.

boardgame.description:
You were extremely excited when the Dungeon Construction Kit you had ordered finally landed on your doormat. That excitement lasted until the moment you opened the box. Unfortunately it seems that some evil blackguard had put a curse on it and you immediately found yourself inside your own kit. Now there's only one thing for it: construct your way out. And while you're at it, kill as many monsters and take as much treasure back to the real world as possible...

A print & play card game where each card can either be a room on the map or an action. The best rooms are generally also the best actions, so you have to choose which is the best way to use each card. The card pool allows you to see up to 12 cards at a time, of which up to 4 will be immediately available for play, so there is a limited opportunity to plan ahead.

Dungeon Construction Kit - Cursed! was designed for the 2013 Solitaire Print and Play Contest.

boardgame.name: Shotguns -n- Saddles
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb/Designer Blurb:

He sat tall in the saddle. His eyes, shadowed by a dusty wide brimmed hat, scanned the buildings in the valley. His features were rugged and handsome, and he had the look of a man who had seen more hardship than one his age should have. He was wide of shoulders and narrow at the waist where the gun hung loosely in its holster. The Colt was old, but well tended, with a worn grip that was the telltale sign of much use.

Shotguns & Saddles (S-n-S) is a cinematic role playing game set in the American wild west. The player characters take the role of cowboys, drifters, the town sheriff, or other desperados. The referee creates adventures for these characters full of fast paced action, nail biting showdowns, and barroom shootouts!

S-n-S takes its cue from the movies, books, and TV shows that dramatized this period. It downplays the importance of specific dates and continuity while focusing on the romance, drama, action, and adventure of a good western tale. This allows the referee to include any of the trappings of the genre, whether historically accurate or not.

S-n-S uses old school type mechanics inspired by the earliest role playing game. The goal was to develop a familiar, simple, yet comprehensive set of rules that can be learned very quickly. While concise, you will find them extremely versatile and able to satisfactorily handle most situations with a minimum of confusion or guesswork.

boardgame.name: Afterlife
boardgame.description:
Afterlife is a narrative driven tabletop war gaming experience. The story of a near-future Earth torn apart by civil war after the collapse of the social order imposed by the Unity Council will be told over a number of separate volumes.

Earth burns as sprawling Mega Cities built for a world of prosperity become brutal war zones and the Unity Council’s authority crumbles away. Dozens of corporations, emergent governments and resistance movements form loose factions and alliances in battles for control of Earth’s resources and technology.

Each new Volume of Afterlife will expand on previously released Volumes, adding new miniatures and rules options, and continuing the narrative to its eventual dramatic conclusion.

The Afterlife Volumes will be player driven and interactive. Players will be able to report back the outcomes of battles and the tactical choices made during campaigns, and the information will be used to drive the next stage of the campaign or impact events in future Volumes.

The game will be skirmish level. The game play will be primarily statistics and D10 mechanics.

boardgame.name: Saving Stetson City
boardgame.description:
from the introduction:
January 5th, 1868. Somewhere in Eldorado County, Arizona. Early on a quiet Sunday, you ride into Stetson City. The faithful folk of the
town are at worship – and most other sorts of folk are probably sleeping off last night’s revelries. Suddenly, the silence is broken sharply as shots ring out from the other side of town. You gallop in that direction, but arrive only in time to see a dust cloud fading in the distance -- riders heading for the hills. Later, trembling townsfolk tell you that Hoover’s Liquor Store was robbed; only the latest in a string of crimes plaguing Stetson City since Sheriff McCade was slain, two months ago. A Committee of Concerned Citizens (CCC) has been formed, but they are no match for hardened criminals, and the situation has reached a dire state. The CCC seeks your help in reclaiming the town, bringing it back from its lawless state. Is the mayhem just the random work of rowdies and bandits, or is there a coordinating intelligence behind some of the criminal activities? There are some decent, brave men in Stetson City -- men that you should be able to convince to join you as hired guns -- but they need leaders. That is where you come in.

Saving Stetson City is a Wild West Campaign Setting developed for use with the Go Fer Yer Gun Game!

listing.notes:
Spieleranzahl: 2 bis 5 Spieldauer: 30 Minuten Altersempfehlung: 7+
COPA - Das Schalenspiel COPA ist mehr als ein Spiel. 18 schöne Holzschalen aus Buche, Ahorn und Walnuss und ein Kästchen voller weißer Bohnen bilden das einfache und variable Spielmaterial für vier verschiedene Spiele. Jedes der vier COPA-Spiele hat einen eigenen Charakter, denn jedes kommt aus einer anderen Spieldisziplin. Durch seine Vielfalt eignet sich COPA als Familienspiel ebenso wie als Zweipersonenspiel. KALA Zwei Spieler säen und ernten Bohnen in einem quadratischen Spielfeld, das aus 16 Holzschalen aufgebaut wird. Das besondere dabei: Jeder Spieler verfügt über eine bewegliche Extraschale, mit der er über das Feld wandert. Gesät werden immer vier Bohnen, die man aus dem allgemeinen Vorrat nimmt. Der Zug beginnt stets in der eigenen Schale, die zum Abschluss versetzt WIRD. Wer mit der letzten Bohne seiner Aussaat ein volles Schälchen erreicht, darf es leeren. Je geschickter sterben Positionswechsel der eigenen Schale geplant Werden, Desto reicher fällt die Ernte aus. RONDA Im Memospiel Ronda dienen die umgedrehten Schalen als Bohnenverstecke. Mit unterschiedlichen Mengen befüllt, werden sie im Kreis angeordnet. Wie im Memory-Spiel werden nun immer zwei Schalen aufgedeckt. Wer dabei zweimal dieselbe Bohnenmenge entdeckt, darf eine der eigenen Bohnen dazulegen. Schale drüber und weiter geht’s. Weil die Bohnenmengen sich beständig ändern, wird die Suche zu einem lustigen Verwirrspiel. Wer im Schalenkreis den Überblick behält, wird als Erster alle seine Bohnen los und gewinnt damit die Partie. HOPPER In diesem Geschicklichkeitsspiel bringen die Spieler den Bohnen das Fliegen bei! Mit einer originellen Wurftechnik werden die Bohnen von der Tischkante aus in die Schalen katapultiert, die in einem speziellen „Tablett“ aufgestellt sind. Wer die vierte Bohne in ein Schälchen schleudert, darf es aus dem Spielfeld holen. Ein turbulentes und spannendes Spielerlebnis, bei dem es darum geht, möglichst viele Schälchen einzusammeln. DA CAPO Der große Bohnenbluff! Alle Hände liegen auf dem Tisch, aber wie viele Bohnen hält jeder Spieler in der Hand versteckt?! Auf „Drei“ werden die Hände geöffnet - wer die meisten Bohnen vorzeigt, darf eines seiner Schälchen füllen. Zeigen zwei dieselbe Zahl, verlieren sie ihre Bohnen und der Dritte darf sich freuen. Der eigene Bohnenvorrat will gut eingeteilt werden, denn bis zur Zielschale ist es noch weit. In jeder Runde versuchen die Spieler sich aufs Neue gegenseitig zu überlisten. Wem es gelingt geschickt zu bluffen und seine Mitspieler zu durchschauen, wird es am weitesten bringen.
Inhalt: 18 Holzschalen ca. 90 Bohnen 1 Spieltablett 1 Bohnenbox
Mit Spielregeln in folgenden Sprachen: DE, EN, FR, ES,RO

boardgame.name: Snapps
boardgame.description:
A dexterity game for 2 or more players.
Plays in 10 minutes with 6 players.
For ages 6 and up .

In Snapps there are 6 blocks and a 8cm×8cm square board and all you have to do is place the blocks onto the board… simple.
Well, yes and no: You see, the blocks have magnets in them, and you must place the blocks without making any of them snap together. The first few blocks will be easy to place but as more blocks get placed, the available space on the board dwindles, and it becomes rather tricky to place the last blocks.

If all the blocks get placed on the board, the game enters a second phase, in which players must take turns to push a block towards the centre of the board. At some point the blocks will suddenly snap together, and the player taking their turn at the time is eliminated. Eliminate all your opponents to win.

Knowledge about the physics of magnetism is not essential; what you need are a steady hand and nerves of steel, because those snapping blocks will make you jump.

Schnapps is the adult variant, in which the player who makes the blocks snap together must drink a shot.

boardgame.name: Hole of DOOM!!!
boardgame.description:
Hole of DOOM!!! is akin to Battling Tops in that players spin tops on a wooden board, trying to push the opponent into the dreaded hole of DOOM! For 2-4 players.

From the Cubiko website....

In late 2012, whilst playtesting 'Clockwise' eight year old Samuel continued his annoying habit of spinning the games delicately designed cog mechanism.

"Samuel stop it! Turn the cogs gently, don't spin them." I pleaded.

Now Samuel is a great playtester and since he seemed obsessed with his spinning discovery, and wasn't about to stop any time soon, I decided it was best to follow his lead.

So there we were spinning the cog mechanism harder and faster when suddenly the smallest cog jumped from its hole and spun by itself. Well that was it, Samuel completely dismantled the wooded mechanism and began spinning each cog individually. Biting my lip, I reluctantly joined in and a game which resembled the classic 'Battling Tops' ensued.

I gradually warmed to the abuse of my cogs, however, our makeshift board was littered with 5mm holes and the spinning cogs would fall as they cross them. Samuel thought this was great and he called them holes of DOOM!

boardgame.name: Scotland Yard Master
Scotland Yard: Digital
boardgame.description:
In Scotland Yard Master — a new version of the 1983 Spiel des Jahres-winning Scotland Yard — one of the players takes on the role of Mr. X. His job is to move from point to point around the map of London by taking taxis, buses or subways. The detectives – that is, the remaining players acting in concert – move around similarly in an effort to move into the same space as Mr. X and capture him. The tricky part is that while the criminal's mode of transportation is nearly always known, his exact location is known only intermittently throughout the game.

Scotland Yard Master includes six additional game elements, four of which are part of a free app for iOS and Android that offers detectives limited tools to locate Mr. X. For example, the detectives can use radio towers to get a rough sense of where Mr. X is located, with the color of the radio waves hinting at whether he's close to each tower. The two-dimensional game board can also be converted to a 3D view, and the detectives can ask witnesses on the buildings whether they've recently seen Mr. X. The app also allows for pass-and-play, with Mr. X having a self-generated PIN so that the detectives can't accidentally discover his location.

Scotland Yard Master also has new action options for Mr. X: "Helicopter" and "Sabotage".

boardgame.name: Pro & Contra
За и против
boardgame.description:
Aim of the game
Players have to make others guess words by giving positive and negative statements about the term in question and without mentioning that word. By doing so, they practice argumentation skills and looking at something from different angles.
Game play
The game can either be played in teams (4 or more players) or everyone against everyone else (up to 5 players). The stack of cards is placed face-down next to the board. Each of the cards has a word on it (e.g. "talk shows", "mobile phone apps", "EU enlargement"). The starting player starts by giving a positive statement about the word on his/her card. If a player guesses correctly, both the player who explained and the one who guessed move 6 spaces on the board. If the word isn't guessed, the same player has to use a negative statement next round, and if successful both players get to move 5 spaces (one space less per round that it takes to explain the word). The player whose token reaches the finish line first wins the game.

boardgame.name: Maja
Maya: El Florado
boardgame.description:
A "Maya the bee" themed memory and dexterity game for children.

Theme
A thunderstorm is coming! Maya the bee and her friends are trying to bring home as much honey as possible before it gets too wet. Who'll manage to collect the most honey?

Aim of the game
Collect the most honey by remembering where the honey is and by skillfully throwing your token in the right places.

Setup
The 32 square meadow tiles (4 water lilies, 6 honey flowers, 22 dandelions) are shuffled and placed face down in the middle of the table. They form the meadow.
The player tokens (Maya, Willie, Flip, Beatrix) are placed at the edge of the meadow.

Game play
Players take turns throwing their player token on the meadow tiles. If your token lands on one or more meadow tiles, you place the tile face-up next to the meadow (if it is a water lily), place it face-up in front of you (dandelion) or place it face-up in front of you and get to look at two of the face-down meadow tiles and place them in a spot of your choice in the meadow (honey flower). If your token lands on another player's token, you have to give him/her one of the tiles you've collected.
When a player turns over the fourth water lily, he/she finishes the turn, and then the game ends. The player with the most flower tiles wins the game.

boardgame.name: City of Zombies
boardgame.description:
City of Zombies is a co-operative, dice-based intense team survival game. Players combine dice to target and remove zombies from an ever-advancing horde before their barricade is overrun.

The game is suitable for all ages and abilities, and can be played in as little as 15 minutes (in the shorter version). The key game mechanics involve manipulating the numbers rolled on the dice via combinations of mathematical functions (from basic addition and subtraction through to squaring and cube rooting) to hit the exact numbers on the encroaching zombie cards - you need a precise head shot to take them out! As a co-op game, the difficulty can be tailored to suit the skills of the players, and supports groups of mixed abilities well.

Originally developed to assist the designer's daughter with her maths, the game has fantastic learning potential for players. It offers number manipulation skills by stealth rather than in a more traditional overtly "educational" game setting. What was designed with educational intent has become a great game for gamers and their families, and suits more experienced groups as a good warm-up or end of night filler.

boardgame.name: We Were Brothers
boardgame.description:
We Were Brothers is the ultimate WWII infantry warfare board game and the first cross-over wargame. The game covers thirty historical missions for U.S., Wehrmacht, British and Italian armies from the three landings theaters in Italy: Operation Husky, Operation Avalanche and Operation Shingle.

We Were Brothers is a cross-over wargame because it effectively blends elements from several game categories. From the wargame it shares historical, technical and tactical accuracy. Every wargamer, from the newbie to the expert one, will be delighted with the level of detail and all the classic elements as LOS, covers, scattering, different weapons, roles, suppressive fire, opportunity fire, off-board artillery support and Clos Air Support, etc. However, the original lean game mechanics Alea Struggle System allows does not use any table, ruler or other complicate measurement method, making the game fast, deep and easy to learn, yet challenging to master.

Between each scenario the random mission generator allows recreating your own historically accurate scenarios in order to complete your personal day-by-day race to Rome: you can generate your soldiers and squad, each one with his own skills and background, put them into battle and see how they evolve in terms of skills as they survive from mission to mission.

The miniatures inside the box and the whole game system is in 1:72 scale. In this way, any add-on to the game in terms of sceneries, vehicles, miniatures and props can be easily purchased by any model store, such as at www.wbsgames.com

Each player leads a team of four men, including one specialist, and fights against the opponent, in cooperation with other teams to form a Squad. The Combat and movement system is very lean since you don't need rulers, tables, charts as the usual wargames, yet it is very historically, technically and physically accurate to be enjoyed by hardcore wargamers. For its mechanisms, the game concentrates on suppression fire/moving and cover to cover maneuvers, simulating the real WWII tactics as well as assaulting impulse.

We Were Brothers is a game system that will be enriched by the Armoured Combat expansion and other operation theaters.

boardgame.name: Cope
boardgame.description:
In Cope each player controls four members of a family who each start the game at a different stage of life (child, teen, adult, senior citizen), or "growth level" as the game has it.

Each growth level is represented by a track which is moved around by die roll. Various spaces on the tracks will require players to draw Good News or Bad News cards. Others will allow the player to try the "Ladder of Life" by coping with a crisis or opportunity. Coping is performed by rolling a large dodecahedron; the result may let the family member cope with the problem and advance, or it may require help from a family member at another growth level, in which case that member has to be moved.

Family members may get "promoted" to later growth levels. The levels are designated by plastic rings of different colors placed on the pieces.

The object of the game is to get all of your family members home first, but the real objective of the game is educational. As the introduction to the rules say, "the purpose of the game is to teach individual and family participation on how to COPE with daily situations in life."

boardgame.name: Shotzee: The Numbers Game
boardgame.description:
In Shotzee each player has a score sheet with four 3x3 grids. On a turn, a player rolls from 1-4 dice (their choice) and then all players must enter the number rolled in an empty space in one of their grids.

After all the grids are full they are scored. Players score for columns in which the first two numbers add up to the third, rows in which the second number subtracted from the first equals the third, and long diagonals in which the first two numbers multiplied together equal the third.

Bonus points are given for combinations where the result (third number) is particularly high, for having multiple additions or subtractions score in one grid, and for "Shotzees," which are multiplications where the result is 21.

As a variant, on each die roll each player must write the number in one box in each of their grids.

Thunder Gods: Kamikazes at Okinawa portrays the massive Kikusui offensive by waves of hundreds of suicide attacks against the Allied invasion fleet off of Okinawa. Each copy of Thunder Gods has three maps, 51 double-sided, un-mounted counters, 5 pages of rules, and 4 pages of historical commentary and bibliography. The game is designed by Paul Rohrbaugh with graphics by Bruce Yearian.

Part 1 of the game was originally published in issue #5 of Panzer Digest. This edition features the other two unpublished modules/games, new graphics by Bruce Yearian, linking "campaign game" rules and 4 pages of historical commentary/designer notes.

boardgame.name: Buzzed Out!
boardgame.description:
A great game to get the party started. Riotous fun designed to bring out your competitive side. Try to guess correctly, the word or common phrase of your team mate in this manic quick fire game. Game contents include word cards and an electronic timer. Don't get caught in possession!
Preperation for the game:
-Split into two teams.
-Decide how many points a team needs to score to win the game. We recommend 8.
-Choose which coloured side of the cards you will play for your game.
-Shuffle the deck of cards and place down in the centre of the table.

Playing the game:
-One player is nominated from each team to be the describing player for the first round, the remaining players on the team are the guessing players.
-Once you have selected your describing and guessing players a member of either team can activate the timer.
-Once the timer is activated the timer ticks for an undisclosed amount of time.During this time the describing player of Team One collects a card from the top of the card pile. Each card features 10 items of phrases. The describing player selects any one of the ten and describes their selection to the guessing members on their team. The description can only be made by voice , no gestures are allowed. The describing player must not use any part of the word or phrase to help their description. The guessing players do their best to answer as quickly as possible.
- On correctly guessing the item or phrase the card is passed to Team Two's describing player who then selects a different item or phrase from the same list of ten. They then proceed to describe the selected item to their guessing players. Again, on a correct guess the card is passed back to Team One's Describing player, who picks a new item or phrase. This process continues with both teams attempting to describe and guess correctly as quickly as possible so they may return the card to the opposing team.
-During this time the timer continues to tick until eventually a buzzer sounds marking the end of the round. Whichever team is left holding the card is the loser!

Tips and points to remember:
1) You cannot predict when the buzzer will sound because this changes each time you play a round.
2) Once a team have guessed an item or phrase correctly the card is deemed to be in play with the other team. Unnecessary delays in handing over the card or taking the card are not allowed. Persistent offenders should be penalised by losing a point.
3) Teams must pay attention so as not to repeat the description of an item or phrase already featured in that round. Repeating words only wastes time for your team!

Scoring:
-The losing team in a round fails to score, however, the winning team scores 1 point.
-should the teams manage to guess all ten items and phrases on the card correctly before the buzzer sounds both teams score 1 point.
-For round two change your describing and guessing players.

Winning the game:
The first team to the agreed number of points is the winner!

Good Luck!

boardgame.name: Drop
boardgame.description:
from the introduction:
In DROP, you and your friends will write a story. To keep this story from devolving into silliness too quickly, its plot is carefully structured.

You will write a story in five parts: a preparation phase where you discuss the basic parameters of the story, and four story acts. Each player will control one crewmember on a starship that’s been summoned to a planet. The crew will descend to the planet’s surface, explore a mysterious landmark, then run for their lives.

You can also play this game yourself, by taking on all the characters’ roles. The game assumes that the players are friends, and that they will freely discuss the ongoing story among themselves. This is not a competitive game, though you can screw over the other players.

boardgame.name: The Green Game
boardgame.description:
The Green Game is an entertaining, enlightening and sometimes alarming way to examine the ecological facts and myths that face us today.

The person who bought the game always goes first. Players roll the die and move their tokens around the circular track. Landing on certain spaces lets the player answer a question. Correct answers reduce the player's carbon footprint, while incorrect answers increase the carbon footprint. Other spaces have players draw "Eco-Warrior" cards that reduce the carbon footprints, or "Eco-Pig" cards that increase the carbon footprint. The first player to reach the smallest carbon footprint on the scoring board (8 points) wins the game.

The Green Game is made from recycled material, soy inks and wooden game pieces.

boardgame.name: Adjugé..!
boardgame.description:
Players acquire various objects at public auction. Each object is present three times: in good condition, in poor condition and a fake object. The goal is to capture as much works of art of great value, avoiding works in poor condition or even fake art.

In each round, the first player turns over a action card. If it shows an auction, the player takes the hammer of auctioneer and take the object card with the starting price 2000 francs. The best bid wins the card, then the purchaser discovers the condition of the object he just acquired!

Some action cards allows player to look at the condition of the object.

The goal is to acquire objects forming series - a series of three objects is double the amount of objects that compose it.
When all the object cards are sold, the player with the most valuable collection is the winner.

boardgame.name: Top! Totem
boardgame.description:
The board represents a grid map of 8 columns x 9 rows with a central zone comprising six central squares and a totem pole in the center!
Each player has 12 pawns and 3 riders. Each pawn moves one step forward or sideways, only the rider can go back. Riders are always moved after the pawns.
All pawns can take a shot at a time, unless the rider who can play two consecutively.
Only pawns can enter the central squares.
The first who eliminates all opposing checkers with at least one of his pawns in the sacred precincts wins a round and scores points. The first player to reach 300 points wins the game.

boardgame.name: GURPS Thaumatology: Ritual Path Magic
boardgame.description:
From the Publisher:

You Can Do Anything!

Magic is a creative force, and those who can harness its full potential can change the universe. This is the core of GURPS Thaumatology: Ritual Path Magic, a complete, stand-alone, and self-contained magic system for GURPS. Designed to emulate the magic of real-world traditions and popular books, movies, and television shows, this framework permits practitioners to cast improvised spells, elaborate rituals, and everything in between. This supplement empowers you to:


Master the traits necessary to become a Ritual Path magician, from specialized advantages to the core and Path skills behind every spell . . . or alter them to fit your campaign needs.
Learn how to craft rituals to produce the effect you want with the skills you have, and what can help or hinder you when gathering the energy to make the ritual work.
Acquaint yourself with the benefits and pitfalls of various methods for making spell-casting easier, including charms, elixirs, grimoires, places of power, enchanted items, and more.
Discover ways to modify the basic system, how to combine it with other magic systems, what awful things happen when you mess up a spell, and exactly what you cannot do with Ritual Path magic.
See how the system works with over 80 sample rituals that cover all the major effects the average caster relies on, such as healing, injury, communication, and protection.


With this system, you can augment the arcanists of the GURPS Monster Hunters series (or other modern-day magical myths), wend new ways for wizened wizards, and provide new possibilities to power for any setting. With GURPS Thaumatology: Ritual Path Magic, where there's a will, there's a way!

boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

Geister der Vergangenheit
von Martin Lindner

Patrick Aylewood ist tot: Mit einem gezielten Kopfschuss von dem vor Wut rasenden Vater seiner Ex-Verlobten erschossen. Die Vertreter des Gesetzes gehen schnell zur Tagesordnung über, zu eindeutig scheint die Beweislage. Und so wartet der Leichnam des Firmenerbes aufgebahrt in einem düsteren Zimmerchen auf die Beisetzung, während der Mörder in seiner Zelle schmort.
Doch seine Tat hat auch für die Tochter und verhinderte Braut dramatische Folgen. Ist denn wirklich alles so klar, wie es scheint? Die junge Frau will Antworten und beauftragt die Detektive, ihr welche zu liefern.
Die Suche führt diese in das Liddesdale am Liddel Water in der Grenzregion zwischen England und Schottland. Eine scheinbar rückständige Gegend mit etwas Industrie und gleichzeitig romantisch verklärt im Zuge der wachsenden Schottlandbegeisterung. Das Land ist zudem reich an Geistern: in den Köpfen und vielleicht sogar echten, Zeugen einer langen kriegerischen Vergangenheit. Da ist es keine leichte Aufgabe, hinter den verschlossen wirkenden Mienen der Schotten nach einer wie immer gearteten Wahrheit zu suchen. Vielleicht aber offenbaren sich die Geister der Vergangenheit ja doch. Wer weiß, was sich im Dunkel der Zeiten und Herzen verbirgt ...

boardgame.name: Tongbrekers
boardgame.description: Tongbrekers (a.k.a. "Tongue Twisters") is a Dutch game in which players draw cards (from a deck of 51 cards), then attempt to correctly utter the tongue twister on that card three times in a row at an ever faster speed. If they succeed, they get to keep the card, which can be used to complete sets of cards for extra points. In addition to the 48 regular cards — which come in eight colors, with two cards in each of three degrees of difficulty — the game includes three special cards that allow a player to attempt to steal a card from someone else. The game ends once all cards have been drawn, and the player with the most points wins.

Rogue Mage Creatures of Darkness Vol 5: Dark Mortals brings you a selection of new foes born of humanity's corruptible nature.

Beneath the minor powers in the infernal hierarchy are corrupted mortals and their hellhole-bred offspring. They are the foot soldiers of the armies of Darkness, and the infernal powers are always seeking to expand their ranks in preparation for future battles.

Dark Human are twisted humans born of the hellholes and possessed by evil at birth.
Dark Mule result when a Dark Mage and human, these elite warriors of Darkness result.
Blackheart, sample dark mule
Dark Mage is what results when a neomage gives themselves over to the Darkness.
Pietra Soul-Drowner, sample dark neomage
Daywalkers are the mixed offspring of entities of both Light and Darkness bestow abilities of a dual nature, making them ideal covert operatives.
A Blood Succubus is the result of a succubus queen who feeds upon a seraph-blooded mortal to feed her unborn brood.
Nightwalkers arise when a mortal willingly feasting upon the blood of certain Dark creatures, transforming them into an accursed immortal.


Rogue Mage Creatures of Darkness Vol 5: Dark Mortals details a number of new, mortal-based enemies to use in your game, and is the fifth such creature PDF released by Christina Stiles through Misfit Studios.
